I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During the operational missions of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in 2004, the 
Government of Viet Nam requested continued assistance to upgrade the power transmission 
network in the northern part of the country to meet the expected future demand growth. A 
project preparatory technical assistance (TA) for the Northern Power Transmission Expansion 
Project is included in ADB’s 2005–2007 country strategy and program update and an ensuing 
loan project is included for 2005. An ADB Fact-Finding Mission visited Viet Nam from 9 to 13 
August 2004 and reached an understanding with the Government on the objective, scope, cost, 
financing, implementation arrangements, and the consultants’ outline terms of reference for the 
TA.1 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Viet Nam was one of the world’s fastest growing economies in 2003. The gross domestic 
product growth of 7.1% was underpinned by strong domestic demand and export growth.2 As a 
result of sustained high economic growth during the 1990s, poverty declined from 58% of the 
population in 1993 to around 29% in 2002. Medium-term annual growth rates are targeted at 
around 7–8%. Economic diversification, industrial development, and employment creation will 
be key in sustaining high economic growth and achieving continued rapid reduction in poverty.  
 
3.  As a result of high economic growth and initial low levels of electricity consumption, 
demand for electricity has been growing at around 14% annually since the early 1990s. With 
continued high rates of economic growth, electricity demand will continue to grow at high rates 
in the medium term. This growth in demand is driven mainly by residential and industrial 
sectors. Due to a rapid expansion of household access to electricity and increasing incomes, 
residential demand grew by 19% annually during the last decade. Industrial demand grew at 
around 13% annually during the same period. With continued modernization and diversification 
of the economic base, industrial demand is expected to grow rapidly by over the next two 
decades. 
 
4.  Ensuring that sufficient capacity in generation, transmission, and distribution is available 
to meet electricity demands is a key challenge facing the power sector. With sustained high 
economic growth rates, the 2001 Master Plan for Power Development for Viet Nam (5th Master 
Plan) was revised in October 2002 to account for updated investment requirements resulting 
from  increased  power  demand  projections.  Total  nationwide  investment  requirements  for 
generation, transmission, and distribution are estimated at $19.1 billion for the period 2002–
2010. 
 
5.  The northern region is the fastest growing region in the country, particularly around the 
development triangle of Hanoi, Hai Phong, and Quang Ninh provinces. This area has also 
experienced a rapid decline in poverty rates. The annual demand growth of 12% in the northern 
region has been driven by a rapid expansion of manufacturing and export industries and by 
increased  household  incomes.  Industrial  and  residential  sectors  have  experienced  annual 
growth rates of 10% and 18%, respectively, over the last decade. With growing investments in 
the development triangle, industrial demand growth is projected to increase by nearly 55% over 
the  period  2005–2010.  To  meet  the  demand  in  growth  demand  in  the  northern  region, 
investment requirements of the power sector are estimated at $5.6 billion over the period 2004–
2010.

6.  Interregional trade has been relatively limited. Currently, the northern region accounts for 
about 37% of the country’s generation capacity and 39% of total electricity consumption. To 
introduce  more  flexibility  and  meet  power  demand  growth  in  the  development  triangle,  a 
backbone north-south 500 kilovolt (kV) double-circuit transmission network, aimed at securing 
sufficient wheeling of power from the south to the north, is under construction and expected to 
be completed by the end of 2005. The proposed Northern Power Transmission Sector Project, 
scheduled for ADB Board approval by the 4th quarter of 2004, will assist Electricity of Vietnam 
(EVN)  in  expanding  and  upgrading  the  500  kV  and  220  kV  transmission  systems  and 
substations to transfer additional power to improve system reliability and enhance the utilization 
of existing and new power plants. The proposed Northern Power Transmission Expansion 
Sector Project was identified as a result of the updated investment needs assessment in the 
revised  5th  Master  Plan.  The  project  will  address  additional  investment  needs  in  the 
transmission  network  required  to  ensure  system  reliability  and  meet  the  revised  demand 
projections in the northern region of Viet Nam. 
 
7.  To support the Government in meeting its reform objectives, ADB approved a TA for 
power sector reform3 that defined a time-bound action plan for restructuring of the power sector. 
A key requirement of the action plan is to reform the legal system. Legal and regulatory reform 
aims  to  provide  a  consistent  legal  basis  to  facilitate  commercial  sector  operations  and 
Government oversight of the sector by (i) promulgating a primary Electricity Law; (ii) developing 
supporting secondary legislation to the Electricity Law to address (a) the scope and structure of 
the regulatory agency, (b) procedures for tariff setting and regulation, and (c) administrative 
regulations and standards; and (iii) preparing a grid code for interconnection and operating 
standards between generation entities and the transmission entity.  
 
8.  The key steps taken by the Government include (i) approval of the draft Electricity Law 
by a high-level electricity law steering committee; and (ii) a decision to corporatize all EVN-
owned power plants as limited-liability companies, except those with multi-purpose functions 
(irrigation and flood control), to prepare EVN for single-buyer operations and ultimately, a pool-
based market system. The draft Electricity Law has been discussed in the National Assembly 
and is expected to be promulgated during 2004. The decree on the creation of a regulatory 
agency will be finalized within 6 months of the enactment of the Electricity Law. On this basis, 
the proposed Northern Power Transmission Expansion Sector Project would continue to support 
efficient and viable investments in the power sector required to sustain Viet Nam’s economic 
growth and poverty reduction.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
9.  The TA will support the Government’s power sector investment program in the northern 
region by assisting in the preparation of a power transmission expansion project to ensure a 
sufficient and stable power supply to end-consumers. The project will build on and expand 
ADB’s proposed Northern Power Transmission Sector Project and serve to strengthen and 
expand the transmission network in the north. The project will continue to support improvements 
in system stability and security, loss reduction, and improvements in the reliability of supply. The 
identified subprojects include (i) installation of a second transformer at 500 kV at Thuong Tin

3
substation; (ii) installation of a second transformer at 220 kV at Van Tri substation; (iii) Son La-
Hoa Binh-Nho Quan 500 kV transmission line (260 kilometer [km]); (iv) Son La–Soc Son 500 kV 
transmission line (260 km); (v) Quang Ninh-Mong Duong 500 kV transmission line (25 km); (vi) 
Ha  Tinh-Thach  Khe  220  kV  transmission  line  (9  km);  and  (vii)  Thanh  Hoa-Vinh  220  kV 
Transmission line (120 km, second circuit). The technical assistance framework is in Appendix 
1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The activities under the TA will cover the following areas: (i) technical design; (ii) least-
cost  analysis;  (iii)  update  of  economic  and  financial  analyses,  projections,  including  risk 
analysis;  and  (iv)  compliance  with  ADB's  safeguard  policies.  In  addition,  the  financial 
management of EVN and the latest developments in power sector reforms and restructuring of 
EVN will be reviewed.  
 
11.  Load forecasts and generation alternatives will be the basis for least-cost technical 
design of subprojects. Feasibility studies will be reviewed, and procurement implementation and 
arrangements  will  be  prepared,  including  contract  packaging  and  project  implementation 
schedule.  
 
12.  Since the proposed individual subprojects, which will not yield benefits if considered in 
isolation, form part of a regional power investment program covering the period 2004–2010, the 
economic and financial analyses of project will include updating the existing macro time-slice 
model and preparing a distributional analysis for the northern power investment program. The 
consultants will analyze the implications of various delay scenarios of generation plants for 
financial and economic results. Progress in economic cost recovery relating to the tariff structure 
and the extent of cross-subsidization between major consumer groups will be reviewed. In 
addition to financial analysis of the project, the financial management capabilities and the 
financial performance of EVN will be reviewed and updated using EVN’s independent creditors 
model.  
 
13.  To ensure compliance with ADB’s safeguard policies on the environment and involuntary 
resettlement, detailed field surveys along the planned alignment of the transmission lines, at the 
sites  of  the  two  substations  for  expansion,  and  of  the  necessary  access  roads  will  be 
undertaken to identify environmental impacts and to prepare a full inventory of all land and other 
affected  assets  and  a  socioeconomic  assessment  of  project-affected  households.  All 
information  will  be  gender  disaggregated.  A  resettlement  plan  will  be  prepared  for  core 
subprojects as well as a resettlement framework to guide in preparing subprojects under the 
loan.  The  resettlement  plan  will  include  necessary  compensation  and  income  restoration 
measures, most suitable implementation arrangements, design of public information, disclosure 
and grievance procedures, and costing of compensation and income-restoring measures. An 
initial  environmental  examination  and  a  summary  initial  environmental  examination  will  be 
prepared in accordance with ADB’s guidelines for environmental assessment for sector loans. 
Subprojects will be assessed according to ADB’s guidelines and environmental assessment and 
review procedures, criteria for subprojects for the loan will be established.  Field visits to collect 
data will be conducted and public consultations in each province will be held and documented. 
 
14.  Before starting any resettlement and environment planning activities, the consultants will 
conduct social safeguard orientation workshops for the Executing Agency (EA) and other 
agencies involved in resettlement planning e.g. provincial and district resettlement committees. 
To improve the resettlement planning process, the EA and its domestic consultants and the

4  
resettlement  committees  will  receive  formal  and  on-the-job  training  in  inventory  of  loss, 
collecting  and  analyzing  social  survey  data,  and  in  conducting  consultations  with  affected 
people.  In  addition,  an  orientation  workshop  on  environmental  and  social  safeguard 
requirements will be launched by ADB staff, with detailed introduction on ADB’s requirements, 
guidelines, and policies for sector loans.  Relevant Government of Viet Nam authorities (e.g., 
the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment) will be invited to briefly preview the 
Government’s safeguard requirements. The workshop will be targeted toward relevant staff of 
EVN, Northern Viet Nam Power Project Management Board (NPPMB), and power engineering 
consulting companies (PECCs). In addition, on-the-job training in environment and resettlement 
activities will be provided throughout the implementation of the TA.  
 
15.  A detailed poverty analysis of the sector was undertaken under the project preparatory 
TA for the Northern Power Transmission Project. As that sector work is considered up-to-date 
and given that the expected benefits will not target particular beneficiaries, the poverty analysis 
will include a review of existing work, and where necessary, update the analysis of affordability 
of up-front connection costs and tariffs.  The project is not expected to cause any specific 
cultural or social effects on any socioeconomic group, including ethnic minority people, or 
exclude any from benefiting from the proposed investment project. Therefore, no specific ethnic 
minority development plan is expected to be required. However, the social analysis will include 
field consultations in the project areas, targeting the most vulnerable groups including ethnic 
minority people to examine affordability of electricity consumption and connection costs. The 
summary initial social and poverty analysis is provided as Appendix 2. 
 
16.  Since the Son La–Hoa Binh–Nho Quan and the Son La–Soc Son 500 kV transmission 
lines will evacuate power from Son La and Huoi Quang hydropower generation plants, a sector 
project  approach  for  the  ensuing  loan  will  introduce  sufficient  flexibility  in  the  event  that 
generation projects are significantly delayed.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $650,000 equivalent, of which the foreign 
exchange cost is $401,000 and the local currency cost is $249,000 equivalent. The Government 
has requested ADB to finance $500,000 equivalent, comprising the entire foreign exchange cost 
and a portion of the local currency cost amounting to $99,000 equivalent. The TA will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The 
Government will finance the remaining $150,000 equivalent of local currency costs through in-
kind contributions of the executing and implementing agencies (IA), and partly from the EVN-
owned PECCs, and the Institute of Energy. The contribution will include office accommodation 
and facilities, local communication, counterpart staff, data and other information needed for the 
TA. Detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 3. The Government has been advised that ADB’s 
approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  EVN, as the EA for the TA, has nominated NPPMB to be the IA. NPPMB has adequate 
experience with implementing externally funded projects of similar nature. PECC1, PECC2, and 
PECC4 are carrying out the feasibility studies for the transmission lines and substations, while 
the Institute of Energy is responsible for system planning and for preparing of load forecasts. 
The TA consultants will work closely with those agencies and have full access to all documents 
and data required for TA implementation. EVN will make sufficient counterpart funds available, 
including those for transport and for field visits of counterpart staff. EVN will also give all

5
necessary assistance to the TA consultants in liaising with other Government ministries and 
agencies  and  provincial  authorities,  and  in  obtaining  necessary  data  and  documentation, 
including high-quality detailed maps for routing of transmission lines and location of substations.  
EVN will liaise with the provinces affected by the proposed investment project to ensure that 
counterpart staff are nominated before the TA consultants are fielded.  
 
19.  The TA will require about 11.5 person-months of international and 8.5 person-months of 
domestic consulting services. It will be implemented over 7-months commencing in February 
2004 with expected completion in August 2005. Outline terms of reference for the consultant are 
in Appendix 4. At the initial stage of implementation, a workshop for provincial and district 
resettlement committees will be held to discuss the work to be undertaken by the consultants 
and ADB’s requirements related to resettlement. Tripartite meetings involving EVN and NPPMB 
will be held after the submission of the inception, interim, and draft final reports. The consultants 
will prepare status reports for the specific scope of their works, highlighting any issues that 
could become critical to the timely completion of the TA. The consultants will arrange for other 
workshops and on-the-job training for EVN and NPPMB staff and domestic consultants and for 
provincial and district resettlement committees as necessary.  
 
20.  The  proposed  subprojects  are  key  investments  for  the  northern  power  investment 
program for the period 2004–2010. It is essential that the proposed transmission lines be 
commissioned at the same time as the power plants to ensure optimal economic efficiency of 
both subproject investments. The loan has therefore been included in the 2005 project pipeline. 
Early implementation of the TA is important for meeting key project processing deadlines to 
ensure timely investments. The scope of work to be conducted for this TA is a follow-up to the 
work undertaken in the TA study for the proposed Northern Power Transmission Sector Project. 
The firm, that successfully undertook the previous TA study, has intimate knowledge of the data, 
models, and the basis for the calculations for the 2004–2010 investment program, having 
developed much of the data and models itself. Since the work will involve revising and updating 
data for the same investment program and the same time period, it would be more efficient if the 
same firm were engaged to undertake the work under this TA.4 Therefore, that firm will be 
engaged by direct selection methods (ref. PAI 2.04, para. 10). The consulting firm will be 
engaged  by  ADB in accordance with its  Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging of domestic consultants. All procurement under 
the TA will be in accordance with ADB’s  Guidelines for Procurement. The consultants will 
procure the equipment needed in the Project. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Viet Nam for preparing the Northern Power Transmission Expansion Sector 
Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.  
                                                 
4  It is expected that any future ADB involvement in the sector would be an investment program for the entire country 
and for a different time period. Therefore, direct selection of the same firm for this TA will not disadvantage other 
firms in future ADB work in this sector.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Viet Nam: 
 
Viet Nam has made remarkable progress in providing electricity services to the population. Nationwide 
electricity coverage is a key objective in the Government’s strategy to reduce poverty and vulnerability. The 
percentage of households with access to electricity services increased from 49% in 1992 to 86% in 2002. 
Demand for electricity has increased substantially in the last decade. Increasing incomes and reduced 
poverty have made household appliances and electricity services affordable. However, annual per capita 
consumption remains among the lowest in Asia at about 321 kilowatt-hours (kWh). Utilization in households 
is even lower, about 158 kWh per year or 13 kWh per month. 
Reliable and good quality electricity supply is key for sustaining rapid economic growth and poverty 
reduction. Reliable power supply is important for continued diversification toward a modern and 
industrialized economy, which will bring about employment, increased productivity and wage increases in 
the agriculture, and service sectors. 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                    Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
A detailed and extensive poverty and social analysis for the power sector was conducted under the 
technical assistance (TA) for the Northern Power Transmission Project. Since this analysis is up-to-date 
and covers the same region, the poverty analysis will include a review of existing sector work on poverty 
issues, and where required, data updates on affordability of connection costs and tariffs. The poverty 
analysis will be supplemented by a distributional analysis of the net economic benefits of the investment 
program, which the proposed project would support. In addition, social field assessments will further 
investigate and ensure that affordability of connection costs and monthly electricity bills among the most 
vulnerable, including ethnic minorities, is appropriately assessed.      
C.  Participation Process

Stakeholder analysis:  
 
A stakeholder analysis will be an integral part of the economic (distributional assessment), social, and 
resettlement assessments. The stakeholder analysis under the economic and social assessments will be 
mainly descriptive to assess the distribution of expected costs and benefits. For transmission line routings, 
information and consultations with people and local communities in affected areas will be undertaken. The 
TA will design a full participation strategy to be undertaken before and under the construction period. The 
strategy will include a design for public information disclosure, compensation and resettlement issues, and 
grievance procedures.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Scope of Work 
 
1.  Team Leader Responsibilities and Engineering Aspects (3 person-months, 
international)   
1.  The consultant will undertake team leader responsibilities and coordinate the work to 
ensure the consistency and quality of the various aspects of the study. The work will include the 
following tasks: 
(i)  Review the latest revision of the 5th Master Plan for Power Development for Viet 
Nam, focusing on the investment period 2004–2010, and the feasibility studies of 
the proposed subprojects; confirm least-cost design for the system expansion to 
meet  the  expected  load  growth.1  Prepare  a  summary  subproject  profile 
containing the major indicative scope of work of each subproject and as its 
justification.  
(ii)  Prepare selection criteria for technical least-cost design, the environment and 
resettlement for subprojects to be included in project implementation; identify and 
provide outline assessments for the additional subprojects needed to make up 
the loan and list the information required to make further assessments that may 
later be performed by the implementing agency (IA) under the loan. Prepare 
templates for subproject analysis and train relevant Northern Viet Nam Power 
Projects  Management  Board  (NPPMB)  staff  in  preparing  documents  for 
submission to the Asian Development Bank (ADB).  
(iii)  Prepare detailed list of equipment and works necessary for the complete Project 
scope, and estimate their costs by foreign and local components. Outline project 
implementation and procurement arrangements including contract packaging, 
and prepare a project implementation schedule.  
(iv)  Review Electricity of Vietnam’s (EVN) institutional capacity in operation and in 
implementing projects, and assess any specific assistance in capacity building 
and technology transfer that will be required. 
(v)  Prepare, coordinate, and conduct workshop activities for tripartite meetings and 
other workshops to be conducted under the technical assistance (TA). 
 
2.  Project financial, economic and poverty analysis (2 person-months, 
international) 
2.  In accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects, Handbook 
for Integrating Risk Analysis in the Economic Analysis of Projects, and Handbook for Integrating 
Poverty Impact Assessment in the Economic Analysis of Projects. The work will include the 
following tasks: 
(i)  Update the least-cost expansion program. Prepare demand forecast scenarios

4.  Environmental Assessment (2 person-months, international; 5 person-months, 
domestic) 
 
4.  In accordance with relevant ADB guidelines and policies for environmental assessment, 
particular by  ADB’s Environmental Assessment Guidelines for Environmental Assessment of 
Sector Loans. The work will include the following tasks: 
(i)  Prepare and conduct a 1-day, joint orientation workshop on environmental and 
social safeguard requirements, which will be launched by ADB staff with an 
introduction on ADB’s requirements, guidelines, and policies. 
(ii)  Review  the  World  Bank’s  “Environmental  Assessment  Template  for  Power 
Transmission and Distribution Projects with Limited Environmental Impacts” and 
consider its applicability as an appropriate method for conducting environmental 
assessment of the individual subprojects.

design,  and  construction  activities,  as  well  as  the  long-term  impacts  during

project such as access roads and pay attention to any specific ecologically 
sensitive areas.

subproject; identify and prepare capacity-building programs needed to implement 
environmental management, and monitoring plans. Assess the environmental 
benefits of the proposed activities; prepare monitoring plans for identified impacts 
and recommend mitigating measures.

requirements (sector loan) of ADB and that of the Government. Specify the IEE, 
environmental  mitigating  measures,  and  monitoring  requirements  for  each 
subproject. Include in the IEE documentation on due diligence work and studies 
on Son La and Huoi Quang hydropower plants. Organize and document public 
consultations.  Prepare  preliminary  cost  estimates  for  implementing  the 
recommended environmental management and monitoring plans.

5.  The consultant will strengthen  the capacity of the Executing Agency (EA) and other

reference. 
(ii)  Provide formal and on-the-job training in all relevant aspects of social analysis 
and resettlement planning. 
 
6.  In accordance with the relevant policies and guidelines of ADB, in particular Policy on 
Involuntary Resettlement (1995), Handbook on Resettlement (1998), Operations Manual (OM)

economic and social conditions of affected people make a poverty assessment 
and a socioeconomic survey of at least 10% of affected people and 20% of

ownership, usage and productivity provided collected by the power engineering

losses  of  households,  agricultural  land,  business  and  income  opportunities,

information, establish  eligibility criteria and entitlements for compensation and

them as follows: (i) inception report, 2 weeks of commencement of services; (ii) interim report, 
within 10 weeks of commencement of services; (iii) draft final report by 15 May 2005; and (iv) 
final report by 30 August 2005.  Tripartite meetings will be held after each report is submitted. 
The consultants will prepare presentations and summarize the findings at the meetings. The 
consultants will also prepare monthly status reports for their specific scopes of work, highlighting 
any issues that could become critical for the timely completion of the TA and that require 
attention from EVN/NPPMB, and ADB.
